frontmatter.title: Plymouth Heights CRC Survey Analysis Report

children.value: Pastoral Search Committee - Congregation Survey Results

children.label: Pastoral Search Committee - Congregation Survey Results

children.value: This report analyzes survey responses from the Plymouth Heights CRC congregation to guide the completion of the church profile form for the pastoral search. The analysis reveals a congregation that values
94% of respondents attend weekly - demonstrating high commitment
Worship services (68%), Community presence (47%), Youth programs (46%), Diversity (44%)
Nurturing youth (69%), Busy lives/priorities (59%), Welcoming community members (35%)
Fostering belonging (mentioned in 31% of responses), Strong preaching, Youth engagement
Mixed - appreciation for structure but concern over recent denominational decisions
Extremely high commitment level among respondents, though this may indicate survey bias toward more engaged members.
No one wants fully contemporary worship
Most value variety and inclusiveness in music selection
music (44), preaching (24), worship (15), good (15), sermon (12), variety (10), liturgy (8), biblical (8)
- appreciation for mix of instruments, styles, and participation
- value for call to worship, confession, assurance of pardon
- specifically praised for depth and use of visuals
“The depth of the worship including all aspects of the liturgy”
“Preaching of the gospel message as the focus”
songs (25), music (18), worship (17), singing (13), sing (12), hymns (8), praise (7)
- several want newer songs and less organ
- more hymn singing, song learning, enthusiasm
- multiple requests to bring back post-COVID
- some want to remove certain rituals (e.g., peace passing)
Desire for contemporary music vs. maintaining traditional hymns
Organ use: some love it, others want less
Formality: some value liturgical structure, others want more casual feel
Most feel current level is appropriate (65% rated 3)
Some want slightly more lay participation (18% rated 1-2)
Maintain current level but create pathways for interested members
Sign-up sheets for scripture reading, prayers, children’s messages
Training for worship leaders and sound/tech team
More energy and passion in congregational singing
Adult Book Studies (Guys Group, Ladies’ Bible Study)
ministry (7), group (7), bible (6), adult (6), study (5), opportunities (5), young (4), youth (3), families (3)
Summer music camp for elementary children
“How can PHCRC better foster a sense of belonging?”
members (17), sunday (10), sure (8), household (8), meals (6), involved (6), fellowship (6), together (5), opportunities (6)
Return to community meals (potlucks, pancake breakfasts, holiday meals)
Sunday coffee time valued but could be enhanced
Regular breaking bread together builds bonds
Deacons should visit new members to explore gift usage
Don’t assume people know how to get connected
Variety of entry points beyond Sunday morning
People feel belonging when they’re involved
“Return to community hospitality with pancake breakfasts and potluck suppers”
“When people join the church, deacons should visit them and part of the conversation should be to explore where new folks would like to use their gifts”
“You can lead a horse but you can’t make it drink” - recognition that some prefer Sunday-only connection
“EQUIPPING DISCIPLES TO BECOME NEIGHBORS; INVITING NEIGHBORS TO BECOME DISCIPLES”
good (18), neighbors (17), food (16), well (15), pantry (15), community (13), friendship (12), neighborhood (12), nights (12), mission (12)
- most frequently mentioned as living out mission
- less clarity on how this happens
- inviting neighbors in but not always integrating them
Appreciation for existing programs, recognition that church “does a lot”
- sports for kids (basketball, pickleball), outdoor activities
- partnering with other CRC churches, agencies
“Unless our numbers grow, we won’t have the people power to expand”
“A church can have too many programs which also turn people away”
Balance between doing more and not burning out volunteers
, with 91% rating 3 or higher. This suggests maintaining current local/global distribution.
More active personal engagement (not just church-based programs)
Walking alongside families in need (deacon support)
The congregation sees itself as strong in
. These are pillars to maintain and build upon.
Challenges with welcoming new members, bridging age gaps, embracing diverse families?
“Congregation does a good job; these aren’t significant concerns”
“We have noticeable age gaps; missing younger/older voices”
“We welcome warmly, but new members don’t feel they belong”
“We struggle with diverse family structures and ethnicities”
Nearly half feel diversity/welcoming is going well
29% see this as a real issue
“It’s the middle ages we are missing - parents of teenagers”
“We are seeing the younger generation slowly moving away from PHCRC”
“Maybe our focus isn’t on the issues mentioned. They may be fulfilled if we know and do God’s will”
Nurturing young people to lifelong participation
Welcoming community members into church life
as the most pressing challenge. This must be a central focus for the new pastor.
What does being “Christians of Reformed accent” mean to you?
reformed (various forms), doctrine, catechism, preaching, theology, confessions, appreciation
“We live in grateful response to God”
“Doctrine is a lost cause at PH” (one respondent)
Some feel Reformed identity needs more explicit teaching
Desire for clearer doctrinal statements on website
Generational differences in understanding Reformed identity
This is a CRITICAL AREA with SIGNIFICANT TENSION
relationship, synod, decisions, support, denomination, sexuality, issues, appreciate, structure, unstable, divisions
“I am glad we are in the denomination”
“Relationship is very good, probably better than many other CRC churches”
“I appreciate that PHCRC chose to remain with the denomination”
“CRC is a resource for us as we explore a new minister”
“I’m grateful for PHCRC’s loyalty to denominational positions on human sexuality”
“We’re on unstable ground when it comes to Synod leadership. Decisions that divide churches are harmful”
“The relationship with the CRC has diminished to virtually nothing”
“While there’s a rich theological basis...the spiritual aspects are being railroaded by traditional political dogma”
“I no longer identify with the official CRC affiliation anymore since its heavy-handed synod decisions”
“It should be that PHCRC supports the synodical decision” (prescriptive)
“I think the Lord should judge people who struggle with their gender. If they love the Lord, who are we to judge”
- some support firm stance, others want more inclusion
- some value it, others see it as divisive
- is PHCRC primarily CRC or primarily local church?

The new pastor MUST be able to navigate this tension with wisdom, grace, and clear biblical teaching. Respondents want someone who can help congregation “live peaceably in a diverse culture with opposing agendas.”
youth (frequent), young (frequent), families, community, outreach, growing, membership, expanding, diversity, programs, belonging
1. Growing Youth & Young Family Ministry (Most Common)

children.label: 1. Growing Youth & Young Family Ministry (Most Common)

children.value: Make church appealing to next generation
Help people feel they truly belong
“Establishing a clear direction for the church. What is our mission now?”
Consider collaboration/consolidation with other affirming CRC churches in GR
“We need to study churches that are thriving to learn if there are practices or strategies we may be able to incorporate”
Top Priorities for Pastor’s First Year

children.label: Top Priorities for Pastor’s First Year

children.value: “Fostering belonging and strengthening youth education and programs”
“First year - focus on sermons, visit all ministries, meet all congregation members, get to know community”
“Getting to really know the congregation...hands-on minister with great preaching skills”
“Establishing a clear direction for the church”
“Becoming engaged in the life of the church”
“First the pastor needs to learn the names of the people he/she shepherds”
“Becoming acquainted with all congregation members on a personal level”
“At end of first year, bring proposal to council on where to focus church’s time and attention”
preaching (dominant), strong, biblical, pastor, relational, leadership, people, community, youth, engaging, warm, teach, love, congregation
Most Cited Qualities (in order of frequency):
“Exceptional preacher and teacher of the word is the number one priority”
“Strong preaching that addresses challenges of our day”
“Easy to talk with for all ages”
“Warm and friendly personality that connects with diverse group”
“Plymouth needs a pastor who is willing to befriend anyone and everyone”
“Pastor who truly loves the Lord and tries to serve Him and His church”
“Ability to lead. Ability to address conflict”
“Long-term commitment to this local congregation” (in light of Ben’s departure)
“Energy and passion to serve not just congregation but community”
“Should not just treat this as a job they can switch from”
“Kind hearted and interested in the community”
“Speaking to today’s concerns with biblical base”
Navigating staff dynamics (“Get along with staff!!!” - mentioned multiple times)
“100% supportive of PHCRC position with Christian Reformed Church” (one view)
Able to connect Gospel/Creeds/Catechism/Confessions to daily life
But also: “Able to hold strong personal beliefs without alienating people who see things differently”
The congregation wants a pastor who is:
How should leadership be shared between lay leaders and pastoral staff?
Balanced approach with pastoral leadership working collaboratively with lay leaders
“Pastoral staff should work with lay leaders but show leadership capabilities”
“Council chair should be an elected elder”
“Pastor should have support from a pastor support group”
“Since our numbers are dwindling, more responsibility has to be on lay leaders”
“About the same as current level” (most common response)
“It all depends on the gifts of the leader”
but looks to pastor for vision and direction. Not looking for heavy-handed pastoral authority, but also not purely congregational governance.
Given the importance of worship and music, here’s additional analysis:
Does current blend of traditional/contemporary effectively meet spiritual needs?
“Employing wide variety gives every heart opportunity to be touched”
BUT: “I would prefer a bit more traditional and less contemporary”
AND: “There is too much formal, traditional hymnody. More contemporary please!”
Mix of organ, piano, praise band
Singing with music notes (not just words)
Music too loud at beginning (for some)
Need to learn more contemporary songs
Organ: some love it, others “less organ, more piano”
Some want more joyful, enthusiastic singing

Maintain blended approach with slight traditional emphasis. Continue variety. Consider occasional “contemporary Sunday” or “hymn festival Sunday” to satisfy different preferences without alienating either group.
Mix of long-time and newer members represented
Various age groups (mentions of seniors, young families, middle age gaps)
Pastor must be excellent preacher and relational
CRC denominational relationship (ranges from very positive to very critical)
How much contemporary vs traditional music
Whether diversity/welcoming is problem or strength
How aggressive to be in expansion vs maintaining current programs
Areas of Concern (Voiced by significant minorities)

children.label: Areas of Concern (Voiced by significant minorities)

children.value: Burnout from too many programs (several mentions)
11. Red Flags & Cautions for Search Committee

children.label: 11. Red Flags & Cautions for Search Committee

children.value: “Long-term commitment...because Pastor Ben did not show that type of commitment”
“Should not just treat this as a job they can switch from”
Some uncertainty about what happened with previous pastors
Next pastor must demonstrate clear long-term commitment. Consider asking candidates about their typical tenure and what would cause them to leave.
“Getting along with staff!!!” and “Get along with staff!!!”
There may be staff relationship challenges. New pastor must have strong interpersonal skills and ability to lead/collaborate with existing staff.
The CRC relationship responses reveal real tension in the congregation about:

New pastor will need to navigate this carefully. Some want stronger traditional stance, others want more progressive approach. Pastor must be able to unite around core gospel while allowing some diversity of opinion on secondary matters.
69% identified youth retention as top challenge. Multiple comments about “younger generation moving away” and “age gaps.”
This is not just about children’s programs - it’s about keeping 20s-40s engaged. If not addressed, church will age out.
29% say people are welcomed but don’t integrate. This suggests:
New pastor must actively work to break down barriers and create integration opportunities.
- able to connect with all ages/backgrounds
- can cast vision and make decisions
Cultural sensitivity and wisdom on divisive issues
Candidates who only want to preach (need hands-on engagement)
Rigid ideologues (either progressive or conservative) who can’t navigate differences
What’s your typical length of pastoral service?
What would cause you to leave a congregation?
How do you view this calling - as career step or long-term shepherding?
Describe your preaching philosophy and style
How do you make Scripture relevant to daily life?
How do you use technology in teaching?
How do you lead and collaborate with ministry staff?
Describe a time you had to work through staff conflict
What’s your communication style with team members?
How do you pastor a congregation with diverse views on secondary doctrinal issues?
What’s your approach to CRC denominational positions on human sexuality?
How do you balance conviction with grace?
What experience do you have engaging 20s-40s age group?
How do you make church compelling for next generation?
What’s your vision for youth/young adult ministry?
How do you see relationship between church and neighborhood?
What’s your personal involvement style in community ministry?
How do you mobilize congregation for outreach?
The committee should emphasize in the profile:
Need to retain and attract younger families
Ability to navigate theological diversity with grace
Visit all ministries and community connections
Listen and discern before leading major changes
The Plymouth Heights CRC congregation has spoken clearly through this survey. They are:
The search committee has solid data to guide their work. The congregation is ready for a pastor who can:
The future is hopeful if the right pastoral match is found.
Plymouth Heights CRC Congregational Survey (68 responses)
Quantitative statistical analysis, qualitative text analysis, keyword extraction, thematic coding
